importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The publication date reflects the current relevance of the story in the context of ongoing climate risks in Pakistan, particularly glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs).

The GLOF-II project was launched in 2017, marking a key milestone in Pakistan's efforts to implement early warning systems for glacial hazards, despite subsequent failures and lack of community trust.
The World Bank’s 2023 assessment of Pakistan’s temperature rise provides scientific context for the nation’s increased climate vulnerability, emphasizing the accelerated warming trend.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Between 2019 and 2022, Pakistan faced nearly 90 glacial lake outburst floods, illustrating a rising frequency of climate-related disasters and the urgent need for effective early warning systems.

keyTakeAways: Indigenous knowledge, including traditional signs like sudden rainfall, animal behavior, and sound patterns, is being used effectively by local communities to predict and respond to glacial floods.

Despite significant government spending on early warning systems (EWS), there is widespread community distrust due to system failures, lack of maintenance, and poor communication with local residents.

A recent report in the Friday Times criticized the GLOF-II project for failing to create real-time links between local human sensors and official rescue teams, highlighting a gap between technology deployment and community trust.

In multiple incidents, local shepherds — such as Wasiyat Khan and Mohammad Hussain — have saved lives using traditional human-based early warning methods, demonstrating the resilience and reliability of Indigenous knowledge.
Pakistan ranks among the top 10 most climate-vulnerable nations despite contributing less than 1% of global greenhouse gas emissions, underlining the global significance of its climate challenges.
The government has acknowledged the failures of EWS, with climate minister Musadiq Malik noting the high mortality and displacement caused by glacial floods.
The UNDP identifies global challenges including financial constraints, technical capacity, data gaps, and communication barriers as common obstacles to effective EWS implementation.

namedEntities.name: Wasiyat Khan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shepherd from Roshan Valley, Ghizer, who survived a glacial lake outburst flood (GLOF) and alerted villagers using Indigenous knowledge, saving their lives.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He represents the role of individual community members in using traditional knowledge to respond to climate disasters when formal systems fail.

namedEntities.name: Mohammad Hussain
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shepherd from Skardu Valley, Gilgit-Baltistan, who used traditional signals (gunfire) to alert villagers during a flash flood, preventing casualties.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He exemplifies the use of Indigenous human-based early warning systems in the absence of functioning technology.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In northern Pakistan, especially in Gilgit-Baltistan, Indigenous knowledge systems — such as recognizing unusual animal behavior, heavy rainfall, or roaring sounds — are being relied upon by local communities to predict and respond to glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs), which are increasing due to climate change. Despite significant investments in early warning systems (EWS) like the $37 million GLOF-II project, these systems are ineffective and poorly trusted due to frequent malfunctions, lack of real-time communication, and poor community engagement. In contrast, shepherds like Wasiyat Khan and Mohammad Hussain have successfully saved lives by using traditional human-based signals such as gunfire and fire, demonstrating the resilience and reliability of local knowledge. Pakistan, ranked among the world’s most climate-vulnerable nations despite low emissions, faces mounting climate risks, with nearly 90 GLOFs between 2019 and 2022. Experts, including the UNDP and World Bank, highlight broader systemic challenges like financial constraints, data gaps, and weak institutional capacity. This highlights a critical need for integrating traditional Indigenous knowledge with formal systems to build trust, resilience, and effective disaster response.
title: How Indigenous knowledge is aiding Pakistan’s fight against climate change
